Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Situation2: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with a severe, fast-spreading infection that requires an immediate and powerful antibiotic treatment.
Story:
I was just about to leave the hospital after a long shift when my phone buzzed. It was my younger brother, inviting me to join him and his friends for dinner. He sounded excited, and I knew he valued these moments together—he’d mentioned before how much it meant to him when I made time for us. I promised I’d be there, wanting to show him that he mattered, that I respected our bond.

But as I was heading out, a nurse rushed over. A patient had just arrived in the ER with a severe, rapidly spreading infection. The situation was critical; they needed immediate assessment and the right antibiotics, or things could turn fatal fast. As a doctor, I knew my responsibility was clear: my patient’s life depended on my expertise and swift action.

Standing in the hallway, I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My brother’s expectation for me to be present, to nurture our relationship, clashed with my duty to my patient, who needed me now more than ever. My heart pounded as I stared at my phone, torn between the two calls—one of family, one of profession—each demanding a different part of me.
